18. 
share in this investigation and freely accepted the 
result it is not easy to ascertain his motive for devoting 
a long paragraph to discussing it. 
I will only comment in one other remark in this 
paper. Near its end on page 470 Mr Dines suggests a 
reason for the local high temperature at the Ship, in the 
proximity of the thermometer screen to the tide crack. 
Enquiry would have informed Mr Dines that not only was 
the ice very much thinner under the Cape Armitage 
thermometer but that open cracks were not infrequently 
found in it which passed within a few feet of the 
thermometer. 
The suggestion shows a lack of enquiry into 
and appreciation of local conditions and would have been 
scouted by any member of the Expedition. 
Whilst absolving Mr Dines of all intention to 
mislead I cannot but think that it is a very great pity 
that a remark of this nature should appear in a grave scientific work published by the Royal Society. 
A similar regrettable want of local colour 
is to be found in the second paper contributed by Mr Dines; 
space does not permit me to notice specific instances and 
I will call attention only to the concluding paragraph, 
page 475. 
In this Mr Dines asserts that increase or 
decrease in the thickness of the Barrier is dependent 
<u>entirely<\u>
